title.narrative: 1. Research / Knowledge and Mobilization - 1.1 .KAP Study 1.2 Legal review

description.narrative:
Conduct a Knowledge, Attitude and Practices (KAP) survey on women’s legal right to add stipulations and conditions in their marriage contract and provide an evidence-based recommendation for decision makers to protect the rights of women and girls in their marriage contract (outcome). The output of this activity is to release a KAP study and conduct 12 focus group sessions, 15 in-depth interviews and fill in questionnaires with a sample of 1200 women and girls.
Conduct a legal review of the existing policies, regulations instructions and legislations about marriage contracts ( whereby society, practitioners, and other stakeholders are more aware of how Muslim marriage contracts can be a tool for child protection, prevention of GBV and domestic violence, and women’s rights (outcome).

activity-date.narrative:
1.1 A Knowledge, Attitude and Practices (KAP) survey on women’s legal right to add stipulations and conditions in their marriage contract will be conducted to measure the extent of awareness amongst women and girls that they are entitled to make stipulations in the marriage contract; a right guaranteed to women by the constitution and assailable by Personal Status Law – Article 19. Surveys focus group discussions, and in-depth interviews with male and female respondents will be conducted.
1.2 A legal review of the existing policies, regulations instructions and legislations about marriage contracts will be conducted followed by discussion sessions with representatives from Civil Status and Passport, Sharia and ecclesiastical courts, Supreme Justice Department in addition to religious leaders, legal judges, legal experts and civil society groups to come up with a position paper and develop a list of sample stipulations that can be attached to marriage contracts.
Final deliverable (a report of the findings) will be finalized mid-February 2021. The dissemination for the KAP will begin with in March 2021 International Women’s Day.
Release a KAP study and conduct 12 focus group sessions, 15 in-depth interviews and fill in questionnaires with a sample of 1200 women and girls.

The output of this activity is to release a KAP study and conduct 12 focus group sessions, 15 in-depth interviews and fill in questionnaires with a sample of 1200 women and girls. Work is in progress to achieve the outputs, but changes to the time plan has been made and work will continue during the second year of the project due to the following reasons: 1) the unforeseen outbreak of the COVID -19 pandemic and its impact on mobility to conduct the Focus group sessions and in-depth interviews, 2) a recommendation by all partners to double the sample of the survey from 1200 to 2500 to be nationally representative of both men and women.
KAP Survey :Because such a large sample is not within the capacity of the research implementing partner, KHF procured and outsourced an organization with strong quantitative research skills and experience to conduct the quantitative survey. A representative sample was purchased from the Department of Statistics (DOS) for the marriage contracts KAP survey – 2,500 households in the North, Center and South of Jordan. A procurement process abiding by KHF policy took place in the form of releasing a tender in the newspaper on 16 August 2020. Six companies submitted technical and financial proposals. As per the procurement policy KHF technical and financial committee met on and reviewed the tenders. Only 3 companies passed the technical scoring, yet their financial offers were above the allocated budget. An amendment to the procurement process was made to accommodate the need of carrying out the survey by telephone as opposed to face-to-face. Wefield Company was selected based on their offer. IRCKHF and Wefield signed a contract on 22 October and conducted a kickoff meeting. The quantitative component began in October 2020, and end in December 2020. The qualitative will run in parallel, and the data analysis will take place in early 2021.
Development of Marriage Contracts survey themes and questions: Following the development of the first draft of the survey, two online meetings were held with the project consultants– Dr. Salma Nims from JNCW, Dr. Sara Ababneh from CSS, and Dr. Hayel Daoud, the Sharia consultant (Shari’a Professor at the University of Jordan) – as well as the PMU, Wefield and the IRCKHF team. The survey questions were revised, discussed and amended. The final survey was sent to Wefield.

title.narrative: Development of Marriage Contracts survey themes and questions: Following the development of the first draft of the survey, two online meetings were held with the project consultants– Dr. Salma Nims from JNCW, Dr. Sara Ababneh from CSS, and Dr. Hayel Daoud, the Sharia consultant (Shari’a Professor at the University of Jordan) – as well as the PMU, Wefield and the IRCKHF team. Marriage Contract Survey

Surveys with people with disabilities, their families and service providers to collect information about their level of knowledge on their rights and available services and to learn about the challenges they faced during the COVID-19 lockdown (with a focus on GBV).

description.narrative: Following the mapping, a detailed desk review on the issue was produced. One of the findings of desk review was the lack of available information on women with disabilities in Jordan. After discussion with project partners, it was agreed to conduct an online survey with service providers, girls and women with disabilities, as well as their families to collect information about their level of knowledge on their rights and available services and to learn about the challenges they faced during the COVID-19 lockdown (with a focus on GBV).The survey has been completed by 101 girls and women with disabilities, 125 family members of girls and women with disabilities and 52 service providers. The results were analyzed and presented to the project partners over a Zoom call

title.narrative: Surveys with people with disabilities, their families and service providers
Surveys with people with disabilities, their families and service providers
KAP study agreement with third party

description.narrative: The KAP study was assigned to a third party with strong quantitative research skills and experience to conduct the study nationally with a sample size increase from 1200 surveys to 2500. The procurement process was undertaken as per the King Hussein procurement Policy and supervised by the PMU Head of Logistics and Procurement Unit . An greement was signed with We Field to measure the Knowledge, Attitudes, and Practices on women’s legal rights to add stipulation on marriage contract among males and females across Jordan, to formulate baseline data on Gender-Based Violence to generate an understanding of the current situation in Jordan, and consequently formulate the most effective and efficient programs, activities, or lobbying on the subject. WeField will be responsible to identify the target population knowledge, attitudes, and practices (KAP) related to stipulation on marriage contracts, and Gender-Based Violence, measure differences in Knowledge, Attitudes, and Practices towards the subject of the study between different segments (Gender, Areas, Age, Socio-Economic Classes …etc., capture past and current experiences in the subject and ways of dealing with the same, and the impact caused, understand people’s expected changes of behavior in the future and adaptation levels to stipulations on marriage contract, identify the important social and cultural norms and the associated behavioral determinants related to subject of the study, and support identifying programs and activities that may contribute positively to face GBV and its implication on society and women’s right with regards to marriage contracts.

title.narrative: The KAP study was assigned to a third party with strong quantitative research skills and experience to conduct the study nationally with a sample size increase from 1200 surveys to 2500. The procurement process was undertaken as per the King Hussein procurement Policy and supervised by the PMU Head of Logistics and Procurement Unit . An greement was signed with We Field to measure the Knowledge, Attitudes, and Practices on women’s legal rights to add stipulation on marriage contract among males and females across Jordan, to formulate baseline data on Gender-Based Violence to generate an understanding of the current situation in Jordan, and consequently formulate the most effective and efficient programs, activities, or lobbying on the subject. WeField will be responsible to identify the target population knowledge, attitudes, and practices (KAP) related to stipulation on marriage contracts, and Gender-Based Violence, measure differences in Knowledge, Attitudes, and Practices towards the subject of the study between different segments (Gender, Areas, Age, Socio-Economic Classes …etc., capture past and current experiences in the subject and ways of dealing with the same, and the impact caused, understand people’s expected changes of behavior in the future and adaptation levels to stipulations on marriage contract, identify the important social and cultural norms and the associated behavioral determinants related to subject of the study, and support identifying programs and activities that may contribute positively to face GBV and its implication on society and women’s right with regards to marriage contracts.
Agreement
Desk Review on Gender Based Violence (GBV) in Jordan:

description.narrative: Thorough mapping on the issue of gender-based violence and women with disabilities in Jordan was conducted and the team found over 37 sources of data including reports and legislation. Following the mapping, a detailed desk review on the issue was produced. One of the findings of desk review was the lack of available information on women with disabilities in Jordan. After discussion with project partners, it was agreed to conduct an online survey with service providers, girls and women with disabilities, as well as their families to collect information about their level of knowledge on their rights and available services and to learn about the challenges they faced during the COVID-19 lockdown (with a focus on GBV).. The survey has been completed by 101 girls and women with disabilities, 125 family members of girls and women with disabilities and 52 service providers. The results were analyzed and presented to the project partners over a Zoom call. Annex : Desk review Arabic & English
